div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.

cell.p: Yesterday was the fifth anniversary of the accession of H.M. King Edward VII.
The Cairo French Charitable Society's Ball is fixed for Wednesday, February 21.
Owing to L' Aiglnn being a somewhat long piece, the performance tonight will commence at 9 o’clock precisely.
A native boy of 6 years was run over by a cart and killed yesterday in the Zawit el Kianieh quarter. The driver of the cart was arrested.
A native was riding a horse in Ramleh yes­terday when the animal took fright at some passing object and threw its rider, who was killed on the spot, death being due to con- cussionof the brain,

The Committee of Fetes met on Saturday evening to arrange the details of the Ridotto which will take place at 10 p.m. on Friday. February 9, at the Savoy Hotel. Invitations will be sent out next week.,

A meeting of the society will take place on Thursday, 25th inst., at 4.30 p.m. at the School of Medicine. Mr. P. S Barlow will read a paper on "The Osmotio pressure of solutions of sugar in mixtures of Alcohol and Water,” and Dr. W. H. Wilson will exhibit "A Micro- Nitrometer.”

The management of Mena House Hotel have arranged to give a small dance on Wednesday next, 24th inst., and as the hotel is well peopled with young ladies keen on dancing, and the Bracaie Orchestra will perform for dinner and the dance, a good turnout of Cairo, society is anticipated.

The bluejackets of the Swedish corvette Fieja landed yesterday afternoon and marched headed by the ship’s hand, to the Protestant cemetery, where they laid a wreath on the grave of the three sailors of the Swedish ship Balder who, three years ago, on that very day, were drowned by tailing from the vessel ►

Mustapha Pacha Kamel has expressed, in one of his latest speeches, a desire that Egypt may become the Japan of Africa—a pacific Japan of course. It is not impossible that the hope of this patriot may be realised. His oompatriots are becoming more and more ardent seekers after knowledge. The proof of this is easy to find in the Berlitz Schools of Alexandria and Cairo, where the number of pupils increases continually. [Advt.].

The Concert on Friday night was given again by the members of the crew of the S S. Seti, and a good entertainment was provided. The programme followed the lines of the former concert, only there were two sketches this week instead of one. The artistes were as follows Messrs. Walsh, Edwards, Hillman, Seiffnrt, Duncanson, May, Thorpe, and Flana ghan, and Mi. William Wood acted as accom­panist as’ usual. The sketches wore entitled, "As Deaf as a Post” and "An Amateur Medico.” Mr. Walsh once more bore the heavier part in the programme, and proved himself a splendid entertainer.

The summons brought by Mr, William Houghton against M. J. Kalfayan for assault was heard before the Monsky Court on Saturday, with the result that Mr. Kalfayan was fined P. T. 100 with costs for assaulting his former partner.

Mr. Houghton appeared before H. B. M.’s Consular Court at Cairo this morning on a charge of assaulting M. Kalfayan. On being asked for his defence he requested the Court to recall the plaintiff. Certain questions were then put to the plaintiff through the Court. Mr. Houghton then gave his account of the inci dent, after which the Court dismissed the action on the ground that it was perfectly dear from documents put into court that defendant had every right to be in the office from which plaintiff attempted to eject him, and that whatever were the facts of the alleged assault, plaintiff had evidently attempted to remove Mr. Honghton from an office in which he had every right to be.

Lord Cromer left Cairo on Saturday night by the 8 p.m. express for the Sudan accom­panied by Mr. Higgins, 3rd secretary to

B.M.’s Agency at Cairo, and by Mr. Craig, archivist to the Agency. Indy Greiner and Lady Beatrice Thynne were both the station, and among the large crowd assembled on the platform to wish Lord Cromer good speed were the Prime Minister, Hussein Pacha Fakhny Boutros Pacha Gbali, Ahmed Mazlo: m Pat ha, Abani Pacha, Watson Pacha, Mansfield Pacha, and many others.
On arrival at Luxor, Lord Cromer and party en barked on the S. G. S. Ibis and left for As­souan. The Ibis was expected to pass through the Assouan dam at noon to-day.

H.H. the Khedive gave private audiences on Friday last to Sir Charles Scotter, M. de Bro- nevsky, the Russian Consul-General at Canea, Crete, Count Charles de Lesseps, Ghazi Mnkh- tar Pacha, M. Amadee B. de Guerville, and to Count von Stadnicky, who presented Count Ignaz Ktasicky, Count Jean Zamoy.-ky, Dr. Wolff, and Mr. Gustave Stein.
H.H. the Khedive spent yesterday at Mon- tazah Palace and proceeded to-day to his estates at Mariout.

H.R.H. Prince Charles William of Sweden left Cairo on Saturday afternoon by the 4 50m. express for Alexandria. Lt.-Col. Watson Pacha, D.S.O., A.D.C. to the Khedive, called at Sh'epheard’s Hotel at .25 p.m. on behalf of

row.cell: his Highness. A special saloon carriage had bank of the River Nile by the 5° parallel of

cell.p: been placed at the disposal of the Prince-, who was accompanied by Mr. C. Belinfante Oatberg and his suite.

On his Royal Highness’s arrival at the Alexandria terminus, Princa Charles was met by the Sub-Governor of Alexandria, who accom- panied him and his suite, in carriages placed at his disposal by H.H. the Khedive, to the Arsenal landing-stage.
Yesterday, on the occasion of the birthday of H.M. King Oscar of Sweden, the Government, consulates, and other public buildings display­ed their respective flags, while the Swedish

row.cell: Swedish Diplomatic Agent and Coastal Genera’, held a reception in the New Khedivial Hotel. Among the callers was HE the Governor, who was accompanied by Miralafi Hopkinson Bey. The visit was returned shortly afterwards. In the evening, Mr. Belinfante Ostberg gave banquet at the hotel, bis guests including, besides H.R.H. Prince Charles William, the following : Mme. Montan, Capt. de Champa,

At the Council of Ministers held at Abdeen on Saturday, under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive, it was decided to leave the choice of the personnel of the Secretariat Department, of the Grand Mehkemeh'to the Grand Cadi. The Grand Cadi’s late secretary is to remain at his post at, Tantsh but Sheikh Yehia will be allow- ed to choose his own private secretary.

cell.p: Wo are informed that an enquiry is being made by the Ministry of the Interior with regard to certain incident recently complained of in our columns by a number of Greek correspondents writing from Tala. It appears that while their account was in some respects exaggerated there is only too good reason to believe that the police officer mentioned was guilty of gross rudeness. He has in consequence been severely reprimanded and transferred to another district, and will not bene­fit 1-y the new regulation increasing the pay of the police.

the statutes, a dividend of P.T. 85 on the ordinary shares and of P.T 35 on the deferred shares, payable on February 5, L E.2,592 being carried to the next account.

cell.p: There were many new faces and frocks to be seen at the Savoy on Saturday night, and the ball-rOom was even fuller than it has ever been at the preceding dances. At times it was almost impossible to get round the room, and equally difficult it is now to remember all those who were present. The dresses worn were really delightful, so fresh and pretty and all of the very latest types. it would be invidious to say who was the best-dressel Woman in the room, but certainly nothing could have been more graceful and becoming than the lovely frock of Coarse lace embroidered with narrow ribbon, which was worn over a pale blue chiffoo underdress. The wide cape collar was of a very coarse lace edged with multiple rows of Valenciennes,and the wearer had an ornament of sparkling tissue on her well coiffed head. Then again a very handsome dark woman was wearing a severely out satin of deep rose, one side of the long tunic in front being em­broidered with velvet appliques ot the same shade the velvet appliques lightly spangled appeared upon the light net draperies of the decolletage. A young fair girl had on an ideal frock qf silk muslin with tiny groups of helio trope flowers upon it. There were ribbon-edged frills at both neck and hem, and the deep corselet was of the same colour.

Very handsome, though not a little danger­ous to herself and the dancers, was the princess s°qnined robe, worn by a very elegant woman There was no other adornment to it rave a short bolero of heavy guipure, bat the eye was bound to follow it as it flashed round the room carrying destruction in its train.’ Another very effective frock was of pink chiffon, with isertions of cream lace, and also appliques of lace, embroidered heavily with pink sequin, this passemanterie forming a bold intertwin- d design in front of the corsage. There was yet another in pink chiffon with wide tuckes, and applications of fine black and white em broidery. Mrs. Wynne was in a soft dress of finest white chiffon ornamented with long lines of doll gold, and long-rayed stars in deep moonlight blue. Mrs Carton de Wiart, who had been dining with Col. and Mrs. Patterson Bey, was in amber satin with lace berthe spangled with.gold. Mrs. Morgan was in cream brocade and carried a handsome lace scarf about her shoulders ; the Misses Pell were in-hand­some lace frocks. Mrs. Rome was in a princesse dress of white crepa-de-Chine, and Miss Begg was wearing the same material in a- soft shade of grey Mrs. Armstrong was in a nadsome deep pink silk, much embroidered and with velvet and Maltese lace at the decolletage. Mrs. Bailey was in pink and Miss hummming in blue crepe-de Chine, and both of the-e frooks were finished at the neck, with straight little tuckers drawn in with black The Misses Coles were in cream net, and the Miles. Villebois were wearing heavily corde 1 crepe of a very pale shade. The latter with the Miles. Janney, who all. three were in cream silk. Mrs. Whittaker had on a lovely soft shade of rown bchiffon, heavily tucked and inserted with lace. The under dress was of Pampadeur silk, the co- burs of which gleamed softly through the laca. Her pretty daughter was in a pink gauze Empire frock with tiny wreaths of ribbon flowers at neck and hem. Mrs. Maclean was wearing black with pink roses in her, hair, and Mrs. Scot-Dalgleish had also tucked a pink rose into her hair. The dress of the* latter was of cream satin, much guaged round the waist and hips, and with a little bolero of spangled lace. Miss ffrench had on a very pretty pale blue chiffon, inset with lace its own colour as well as cream, fhe insertions being interspaced with bosses of tinsel tissue Her friend, Miss de Vahl, was in black with a deep collar of fine lace. Miss Kirkbride was also in black, but there were oountless rows of gold sequins embroi­dering it Mrs. Vale tine Smith had on a heliotrope satin with many ban ’s of passe­manterie trimming, and Miss Ambridge was in pink with rushing and lace insertions. Miss de Bilinski was wearing a black sequin­ed robe over white, with cerise sash and choux of the same colour on the chiffon vest, Mrs. Wild was in cream lace with ceinture of Pompadeur silk, ard Miss Nun- goyich was in white with many soft bebe frills. Miss Lampion’s dress was of lace over pink satin, and the shoulder straps were formed of wreaths of roses. Miss Rees had a dress of pa’e blue crepe de Chine with draped cretelles and long sash ends Mismiss
was in cream lace with sarin choux of the same. Mrs. Phillips was in pale green with lace at the neck, and Miss Phillips was wearing yellow with a lightly diamentee berthe.

El Miralai Macauley Bey, Director of Sudan Railways, accompanied by El Kaimakam Sowerby Bey, Traffic Manager, left by ex­press train on the 5th inst. for Atbara to establish their headquarters there. The English and Arabic headquarters' staff will leave here tomorrow for Atbara.
the Khedivial mail steamer Dakahlia arriv­ed from Suez on the 6th inst. with a large number of officials for the Sadan Customs, such as inspectors, estimators, clerks, etc.

Mr. Sequino one of Mr, Urqohart’o bridge foremen, was accidentally shot in the month with his own revolver in his camp at Kilo­metre 76, Suakin-Atbara line. The accident occurred in this wise. Mr. Seguino had care­lessly placed his revolver on the table and it fell on the ground. Whilst bending to pick it up the trigger went off owing to the con­cussion and the bullet entered his. mouth through the bottom lip, knocking two ot his lower teeth out The teeth happily prevented the bullet from making any farther progress and there were no fatal consequences. After being a few days in hospital he is perfectly well again, but his speech has been slightly affected owing to the bullet grazing his longue.

A large number of Sudan se pilgrims are constantly arriving here since the establish­ment of the railway. About 250 of them left for Jeddah by the Hadgi Daood steamer Ales­sandro at the low rate of P.T. 20 a head.

The Khedivial Mail steamer Keneh arrived here on the 10th inst. to take pilgrims to Jeddab. While the Keneh was at Yambo, the chief officer Mr. Papadachi, fell into the ship’s hold, fracturing his skull. .He died here on the 11th and was buried in the Christian cemetery on Quarantine Island. The funeral was well attended by Europeans and the ship’s crew. The Keneh. flew her flags half mast.

The Sudan Government steamer Hawk left this morning for Port Sudan with El Kaimakam Drury Bey, Controller of Sudan Ports, and El Kaimakam Saddler Bey, kirector of Sudan customs on board. Both have gone to establish their headquarters at Port Sudan. The Hawk also towed an iron barge loaded with field guns for Port Sudan which will be used to salute Lord Cromer when he arrives there.

construction of the Unionist party. The * Morn­ing Post” desires that the leadership should be entrusted to Mr. Chamberlain, while, the “Daily Telegraph” prefers Mr. Balfour. The “Spectator” urges the necessity for reconstruc­tion on a Free Trade basis and mentions Lord Cnizon, Lord George Hamilton, the Duke of Devonshire, and Lord Balfonr of Burleigh as possible leaders. (Reuter)

div.p:
THE PRUSSIAN FRANCHISE.
GREAT SOCIALIST DEMONSTRATION. Berlin, January 20.
a humdere meetings have been called for to morrow in Germany to assert the people’s rights. Important measures to maintain order have been taken.(Sava-)
Berlin, January 20.
The social democrats are planning a huge demonstration in this city and in the outlying suburbs,' which is to take place to morrow, in favour of reforms in the Prussian franchise. The polioe has given'notice that excesses will, if necessary, be repressed by the strongest measures that the law permits. (Reuter) Berlin, January 21.
The Socialist demonstration in favour of reforms in the suffrage was most orderly. 92 meetings were held in different parts of the city. police were stationed everywhere, but no collisions took place. A strong force of troops was held in readiness at the Castle. (Reuter) Berlin, January 21.
The Socialist meetings commemorated the Russian revolution incident is reported/S.)
“ RED SUNDAY.

cell.p: The most stringent measures have been taken here, at Moscow and elsewhere, to prevent demonstrations on the occasion of the anniversary of “Red Sunday.” Workmen are observing the day as a day of mourning. (R.)
St. Petersburg, January 21. Four hundred and seventy revolutionaries have been arrested at Krasnviarsk. Twenty- five pillagers were shot at Liban. (Hava-.1
The attitude of President Castro towards the American Minister is irritating the Go­vernment. The French naval demonstration will be viewed complacently. (Reuter)
The "Temps” says that President Castro of ' Venesuela threatens to fire on the French ' ships approaching the coasts. (Havat)

The Army. Estimates for 1906 show an in­crease of £1,860,000 and the report on this augmentation points out that Germany’ expen diture during 1905 was fi/e times that of France. It urges the necessity of being ready for all emergencies.
French Socialists are holding many meetings to sympathise with their Russian comrades.
The Dominicans here and at Constantinople have hoisted the Italian flag. (Havat)
The successor of Baron von richtofan is M. Tschirk and Boegendoiff, Prussian Minister at Hamburg. (Reuter)
The British China Squadron has passed ' 'four days’ festivities here. (Reuter)
AS SEEN BY A Brown owl

The brown owl sat on a gold mohar tree in Colombo’s garden and looked across the grassy plain which stretched in front Of him. He often rat thus on the edge of the wood on sunny afternoons and pondered over what he saw.The plain on which he looked was enclosedbby high iron-spiked railing whcih bore the inscrip

Inside, all day long, men and women pursuer balls of different sizes and shapes and after much thought our garden philosopher decided that the enclosure must be a beautiful institu tion for wealthy lunatics. The younger lunatic rode ponies and pursued a bamboo ball fron end to end of the plain. But the great majority men and women, walked round and round tb enclosure. They were accompanied by black attendants who at frequent and uncertain intervals handed them implements with whioh they struck a small white ball about tb size of a hen’s egg on all the faces he observed the strained and tense looks of unhinged minds. One man in particular he observed II was of the bulldog type and seemed to be 1 sort of king for he struok the ball harder am much more frequently than tbe other inmates and occasionally with fierce looks arid angry words would quarrel over some technical poin of their strange occupation.

But this afternoon I am telling you of tb brown owl observed a strange unrest among the inhabitants of the plain. It was evident that some very important event or oeremon was about to take place. One by one the lung tics collected on the grass below until they must have numbered thirty. They were dressed beautifully as peacocks in the spring, resplen dent in many colored striped jerseys. The; strutted about on the plain admiring their own legs and eyeing one another with disdainful glances; now and again they would make shot rapid runs as mating birds do aid utter Strange cries as they threw to and fro a large brown leather egg-shaped ball.

These performances interested'the owl. H thought that the lunatic breeding season wa about to commerce and some contest take place by means of which the most powerful am best-dressed males would obtain their mates , Two lunatics he selected as likely to prove successful in the survival of the fittest. Tb first stood a bead and shoulders higher thai the other males—a noble figure but alas ! no in his first youth. A slight thinning of hai over his temples showed that this was not th first year by many in whioh he had struggle and conquered. The other was a young man sturdy and thich as a young oak. he was attired in all the colours of the rainbow. Hi face, placid and good tempered, made the brown owl wonder if he really was insane.
As the astonished bird watched the Strang antics underneath him a weird noise arose from the far corner of the plain and as he listened the sound grew louder and closer.

It reminded him of the incessant cries of i parrot in the early morning. Then he saw the noise proceeded from a male inmate. Hethought it must be a warder for the man carried a whistle and wore a quiet coloured suit. Other wise he seemed as mad as the rest. Why if he was sane did he make that continual chatter ing sound, why walk in that peculiar jerky way But ha was evidently the master of the afternoon's ceremony for when he arrived and blew the whistle all the lunatics ranged them­selves on opposite sides and began the contest.

It was the strangest sight the owl had ever seen. Sometimes the lunatics would crowd over tbe ball like swarming bees as if they were trying to hatch something out of the brown leather egg. Then out it would come from their-midst and be seized by one more aotive than the rest who would clasp it to his breast and run. Not for long though, for he would be seized by the other contestants and hurled to the ground and .the swarming operation commence again. After a time; the weakest males limped off the ground and some of them lay down among the, bashes and were very ill Indeed.

So the brutal contest went on until it became evident to our garden philosopher that the tall lunatic and the sturdy youth would be the viotors. Whenever the latter got the ball he would run straight through the other males scattering them right and left until ho placed the ball between two high prists. The owl hooted with delight whenever this happened and came to the conclusion that each of these efforts meant another wife for the sturdy lunatic. This was as-it should be, but why should the tall male strive so hard ? He did not look domestic ; his appearance suggested unlimited bridge. ,

At last the end arrived. Six times had the sturdy youth grounded the ball! between the posts when the warder blew a shrill blast on his whistle. The lunatics limped away and the brown owl with a final hoot flew into the garden, where he recounted to his wife the. strange events which bad taken place.

to the Editor of this egytptian Gazette Dear Sir, - Will you allow a passing stranger a little space in your columns to plead fo’ those horses I sea driven with very tight bear iog reins here? There are many very high class horses in Alexandria, whioh would be a credit to the Park in London or the Bois in Paris but this effect is spoilt by their heads bain; tightly reined np in a very unsightly manner occasioning them a great deal of pain, as well as Hindering their speed and freedom of action I have lately come from Paris, where the smartest turnouts entirety without bearing reins. In England the Duke of Portland (late

Master of the Horse), one of onr greates authorities on horseflesh, has written strong!; to the papers against the practice ; he goes s far as to say when he meets tightly beared up horses he knows the carriage will contain but 2nd or 3rd rate occupants.

Be this as it may, but it the owners wool, watch as I did yesterday, horses standing in the street, turning their heads from side t side in the vain endeavour to obtain relief t their tortured muscles, they would, I feel sort order the removal of thia unsightly and cruel

Horses so cripple become unsound from the inevitable distortion of\the windpipe hen kept at an scute and unnatural angle ; they are also more apt to fall, as it impossible for them to see where they place their feet. trust ing I may not plead in vain.—Yonr obedien servant,

cell.p: LEADING HOTEL IN THE ETERNAL CITY.

The question of management is one of the first importance in connexion with public com­panies, and in Egypt it is particularly desirable, for many reasons that an English oompany should be managed by an Englishman, of well- known integrity, possessing special capacity for business, and a good knowledge of the country. Unfortunately too many of the recently formed companies have been floated by. professional oompany promoters, who pay little regard to the personal character of the manager, and ap­parently attach but little importance to the question of his local repute. The Levantine, resident of Egypt it is difficult to determine’ his real nationality—is not always distinguished] for a high standard of commercial morality; and, though he may find means to produce a divi­dend tor shareholders in the first year, or two, it is usually quite unsafe to allow him the, management of affairs of a company whose, directors reside in England. In the course of a speech delivered in London last June, Lord Cromer said

“Capital is now floating from England and other countries rapidly into Egypt, and provid ed, asjs often the case, that it is devoted to sound commercial industry, it is very welcome. But we want no more company mongering. We do not want companies whose share capital is watered to the extent that all trace of the original spirit has almost entirely disappeared. We shall certainly do our best to resist the invasion these gentlemen, but the public themselves must be their own principal guard­ians, and those who are asked to invest in companies that are now floated I would advise to look carefully to facts,and to judge for them­selves, whether the enterprise is a good one. More especially would I advise them, in cases where quotations are made from official and other reports, to go to the origin of those reports and to see whether the conclusions that can be drawn are in fact the conclusions which they are invited to draw by company promoters. The British name has hitherto stood very high, and I should be extremely unwilling that name should be in any degree tarnished."

Among the reputable companies formed re­cently, I mention the New Egyptian Company (Limited), the Egyptian Estates (Limited), and the Egyptian Investment and agency (Limited) as instances where really good work is being done, benefiting the country and at the same time employing capital profitably and honestly; these three companies are guided by upright and capable Englishmen.

Egypt presents an unusually varied field for profitable development schemes in connexion with the reclamation and improvement of agricultural land, the purchase of building sites, and construction of blooks of dwelling , houses and business premises. The great rise in the value of land which has recently taken place is oertainly very remarkable. Twelve . years ago 33,600 acres of 8tate lands were sold at an average price of about £22 per acre. In the same year the Daira Sanieh sold 30,670 acres at about £5 per acre, this price repre­senting fully 23 years purchase of the net revenues during the preceding-five years. Eight years ago, 11,840 aores of State lands were sold by auotion for £26 123. per acre, and 1,423 acress off Daira Sanieh land yielded an average of £33 16s. per acre. In the following year 13.774 aores of the State lands realized , about £25 10s. per aore. It is interesting to , compare these figures with those of more recent sales. Two years ago the State Domains Administration sold 2,958 aores by auction in : lots averaging 21 aore°, and the price realized was £64 17e. per aore, although the estimated value was only £26 6s. per acre. On one occa­sion there were no fewer than 159 bidders for 27 lots. This is all indicative of the excessively

competition among the native farmers to possessors of the land. Last year 18,561 he Daira sanieh estate were sold at ;e prioe of £36 10s. per aore. The rent his estate in -1901 amonnted to an if £2 15s. per aore. Last year it had to no less than £6 1 IS. per aore. numerous offers have recently been to purchase the large tracts of land to the Government, many of which, thought, will benefit greatly by the irrigation projects now under considera­tion, but unless conditions can be obtained which will be really advantageous to the country, the Government has been advised by Lord Cromer to decline to sell Good land which requires no reclamation will be sold in small plots, so as to give the fellaheen a fa r chance of purchasing it. As regards land which requires reclamation, it must manifestly be Bold to individuals of wealth, or to companies who are in a position to spend capital upon it. With the object of preventing land jobbing as far as possible, every effort will be made to attract purchasers who honestly mean to reclaim the land thoroughly, and who will not sell it until thia has been effected.

The policy of the Egyptian Government has been to endeavour to maintain the small proprietors, and, whilst offering all reasonable facilities for the employment of European capital in land development, to do nothing which would tend towards outsing native pro­prietors and substituting Europeans in their places. Most of the native farmers have neither means nor inclination to sink money- in the improvement of poor or indifferent quality land; but when other people have improved it, they compete with one another to a wonderful extent in their eagerness to possess it. Usually the first essential improve- i ment calling for the expenditure of capital is drainage, and no form of expenditnre is more thoroughly appreciated by the population of

Egypt generally. It also yields a very quick return. There are no restrictions as to the purchase of real property in Egypt by foreigners; they can acquire, hold, and dispose of it with the same freedom and in all respects in the same manner as natives. The ownership of land is absolute, and can be secured by a sound title registered in the- Tribunals. At­tempts have been made by certain financiers this year to depreciate the value of land in Egypt with the apparent object of deterring fresh competitors from extending their opera­tions to this country; but this little artifice was too thin to deceive many people, and there is a gene-al feeling of confidence among the highest and most experienced authorities on the sub­ject that land in Egypt has not yet reached its top value.

With regard to building property, the con­struction of dwelling houses in the new and fashionable quarters of Cairo and alexandria is proceeding at a great pace; but house rents are very high and constantly rising, and the masses of the people are restricted in coin- sequence to the old quarters, where they Are huddled together in the most bewildering manner amidst the foulest surroundings. I quote Lord Cromer’s allusion to this subject is his 4898 report : —

“Almost every house in the native quarter of the city (Cairo) contains an aooomulatipn of refuse and Mrit'to the depth of several feet. This cannot be throw into the street, and the funds available do not as yet permit of its removal upon any extended scale. Dwellings of this nature are consequently centres of pollution and, in the case of an epidemic, of infeotion.”

cell.p: Professor Friedrich preisigke, of the Uni­versity of strassburg, has been engaged on the translation certain ancient Egyptian papyrus MSS. which he recently discovered at Cxyphyn- chus, in Egypt. He has come to the conclusion- that the art of stenography was ‘ oertainly known to the greeks Egypt. in a letter from a certain merchant, nnameded Dionysius, to his sister, didyme, dated November 15, "27 years after Christ the merchant complains that his sister has not written to him either in the usual character or stenograph’ically. Hieroglyphics.

The thoughtful aritcle by M. de Morgan in the current number of the liecueil de Tra- veaux is full of interest not .'only for Egypto­logists, but also for all those who have endeavoured to trace mans. earliest efforts to preserve inscribed records for the use of posterity.. He tells us that, of ; the , three separate systems of early writing known to us, the Egyptian hieroglyphics were speedily de­based by’ the use of more tractable materials than the stone or wood on which they were originally, carved, until they lost all but a distant resemblance to the original characters; while the Chinese, from a similar cause, be­came mere groups of commas arranged in a conventional order. On the other hand, the writers of cuneiform, having in the day used by them a medium occupying a middle place between the excessively hard stone and the easily stained papyrus or paper, preserved more completely'in . their cursice writing the trace of the original pictographs ’.than did -the, Egyptians or Chinese ; and M. de Morgan thinks that he is able to reconstitute some of these on the tablets of uncertain] age dis­covered by him at Susa, which he calls proto- Elamite Thus he thinks he can identify in the groups of wedges the representation of different forms of pottery, of plants, of forks, combs, and axes, and of harps, bows', and arrows, be­sides some more doubtful animal forms. The' instrument used for producing .these was, i»' his opinion,'a style of prismatic form ending in a triangular point. The source the clay used iis still problematical, as he found by experiment that that actually existing in the country is unfit for the purpose, having too great a proportion of sand to bake or dry well. Burial Bites In Egypt.

In a leading article in the “Lancet" some years ago upon the “Ethnological significance of ancient Egyptian burial Rites,” a somewhat full description was furnished of the early prehistoric intements of Egypt,-from which we find that the skeleton was completely broken up and the bones were arranged in a symmetrical order in a cavity in tho , which in these primitive times served as a sepulchre.,, It was- considered that these kind of burials were those of a race different from that of the so called “anoient Egyptians,” and that all historical traces of the burial practices of what may betarmed these proto-Egyptians had been lost.

M. Moret, however, in a recent work upon the “Daily Divine Worship in the Egyptian Temples,” in referring to several chapters, some of them accompanied by illustrated vignettes, inscribed upon tombs, edifices or papyri, proves that a whole series of rrituals­tic incantations allude to and indeed derive their origin from these funerary practices. The proof of the first fact occurs very convincingly in chapters 20 and 21 of the “RiUal of Ammon,” preserved upon a papy­rus snow at berrlin, and also upon the walls of some- temples, a work that has only recently been translated. It speaks of the presentation, as an act of worship to the god, of perfume and oil on purpose to produoe the orderly rearrangement of his bones and -mem­bers, actually asserting that his skeleton wil|’ be put in order. At the same time other passages of the ritual speak ot the Deity as a mummy, thus indicating that in the diurnal temple worship, for this papyrus is the rubric for this official cult, not only was the god assimilated to a mummified hero, but that he also had to be adored by acts or incantations.

These ancient rituals, therefore, afford. a mingling of the practices of the alien races or of the earlier and the later ones of- the same people. The .skeletons discovered Prof. Petrie and M. amelinesu and M. de Morgan upon sites of the earlier Egyptian places of sepulchre had been effeotually disar­ticulated and oaretolly rearranged, and the' faot that the ritual for the worship of the gods in many oases deified ancestors and chiefs ooqtains texts speaking of the replacing, or rather the readjustment, of the bones of the skeleton to their original serial order, distinctly 'declares a recollection of an epooh in which the skeleton- was broken up and arranged quite otherwise than in lift The idea that the reconstruction of the dismember body was a necessity in order that the spirit might again haver a fit tenement to occupy runs through the rubrics required to be recited at 'religious fetes through almost all Egyptian' history.

The Cambridge University Press has just issued an edition of Bacchylides which crowns the series of .publications relating to work of Greek literature recovered from Egyptian papyri during the last fifteen years. Three works of first-rate importance for Greek literary history have been thus gained during this period,Aristotle’s 'Constitution of Athens,“the Mimes of Herondas, and the poems of Baooliylides. In each case the course of' development has been curiously similar. In each case the papyrus has been acquired by the British Museum, and the editio princeps has emanated thence; in each case the'bulk of the subsequent criticism, which has brought tig text of the new author to an approximate!) settled state, has proceeded from Germany and in each case what may be called the full dress edition, with its apparatus of introduc- tions, critical notes, and commentary, has been the work of England. It is noteworthy, more over, that in each case this full-dress edition has been produced by a Cambridge scholar. Oxford has had a predominant share in the discovery and first publication of Greek papyri but when they have once been published, the resident scholars of that university have apparently washed their hands, of them, and taken no part .in the subsequent labours connected with them.

row.cell: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound.

THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompany­ing description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and at' will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

cell.p: This depends partly upon the month In which you leave Egypt, tor Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uni­formly warm than many other places in Europe Many people leave Egypt far too early in the
, for as a rule the weather in April and ay is perfect. The warmest place to go to On leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list snowing the time oc­cupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
The long sea routes—from Port Said or
Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton,London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The j short ones are as follows :—
Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi 3 days j
PortSaid Or Alexandria to Marseilles 5 „ j

The steamers, of the P. & o. North German j Lloyd, Orient and Messageries ’ Maritime^ are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train ’journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 j hours!

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria Liverpool The German Levant line has also good steamers from-Alexandria to Hamburg. . .
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. & O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the. Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express front Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, ft must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The Quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris” and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as Soon as possible after receiving the Indian
mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are. called the* “Ferry boats,” having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from' leaving Port Said.

cell.p: The direct route to sicily is by the Florio- Rnbattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alex­andria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charm­ing and popular places on the island. Giardini is he station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in b.c. 413, and taken by the Romans in b.c. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of 8. Giavannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.
The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rnbattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento you can drive tool will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence iteelf the churches and galleries are of absorbing inte­rest, whilst the local promenades and excur­sions should not he omitted. The Ccudne is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that te Vallom- brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet, above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence bv cog­wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, ‘ and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

GENOA (La Super ba).—The most picturesque and interesting oity in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most an- | cient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa, Then there are the superbly decorated medie­val churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the in­comparable Campo Santo filled with its won­derful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by’ rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monu­mental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAG­GIORE, a renowned health resort on: account of its thermal springs, Change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half an hour you are at Salsomaggiore. r

div.p:
NORTHERN ITALY Continued
and
. The ITALIAN LAKES.
VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea­port The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, horn of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Cam­paniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises. like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by tram by way of Monza :
Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBl O is a charming spot.; then oome Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, ana Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellagqio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and- three-quarter hours

cell.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as “A cluster of delights and grandeurs.

LUGANO'is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charm­ingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and Mr Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from* Beilin zona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggioro, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town,is worth a visit, as it contains interest-
ing paintings, "entombment" by Cisen, and 'The Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE.—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the rigi and Pflatue and the- snow clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are channing,. and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

TheLike of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the rigi Pilatue, Burgen- etock and Son-timberg neeaing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake 'can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne' to Fluelen is a source of delight, to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from ’Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Aaeritrauf. .

A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlit, is made from here, and the* panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND.—INTER­LAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine Walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also, not far from the famous waterfalls, Gieeebach, Trummelbach and Staubboch. Then also the glaciers of Grir.dtlwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux. and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people io Summer and Winter.

div.p:
GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alex­andria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.
If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty . of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
